marketNews.title: Menanti Formula Kenaikan UMP 2025
marketNews.content: The government will announce the formula for determining the provincial minimum wage (UMP) for 2025 in the near future. The formula will replace the one set in Government Regulation No. 51/2023, which was annulled by the Constitutional Court last week following the removal of the labor clusters from the Omnibus Law. Vice President of the Confederation of Indonesian Workers' Unions, Kahar S. Cahyono, said his organization met with the House of Representatives and the government on Wednesday (6/11). In that meeting, Kahar said the Ministry of Manpower proposed that the alpha variable in the UMP formula be divided by industry type, with the alpha variable for labor-intensive industries ranging from 0.2-0.5 and for capital-intensive industries around 0.2-0.8. The Ministry’s proposal is lower than the Confederation’s demand for an alpha of about 1-1.2 to preserve purchasing power in 2025. The alpha variable is an index representing the contribution of labor to provincial or city/district economic growth. In Government Regulation No. 51/2023, alpha was set around 0.1-0.3, which is multiplied by economic growth and then added to the inflation rate to produce the UMP increase rate. Another proposal from the President of the All-Indonesia Workers’ Union, Mirah Sumirat, suggested that the 2025 UMP formula should also consider projected inflation and economic growth, and include 64 items of a decent-living component. In addition to changing the UMP formula, the government will reinstate sectoral minimum wages (UMS) that were removed by the Omnibus Law. The UMP setting period ends on 21 November 2024, with the latest announcement of city/district minimum wages due by 30 November 2024. Labor market analyst Timboel Siregar said the government should postpone the 2025 UMP deadline so that the Regional Wage Board discussion is not rushed.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia Retail Sales Outlook for October 2024
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia estimates that retail sales in October 2024 will grow +1% year-on-year, although a contraction of –0.5% month-on-month is projected. Retail sales in October are expected to be supported by higher sales of cultural and recreation goods, spare parts and accessories, and the apparel sub-segment. In September 2024, retail sales recorded a +4.8% year-on-year increase, despite a –2.5% month-on-month decline (versus August 2024: +5.8% year-on-year, +1.7% month-on-month) as consumer demand fell after the end of various Republic of Indonesia anniversary discount programs.

marketNews.title: Hashim Djojohadikusumo on Renewable Energy Plan
marketNews.content: Hashim Djojohadikusumo, the brother of President Prabowo Subianto, said the Indonesian government plans to offer opportunities to foreign investors to build 75 GW of new renewable energy capacity out of a total of 100 GW additional capacity to be added over the next 15 years. The additional capacity will include solar, hydro, geothermal and nuclear, while the remaining 25 GW was not detailed. Installed electricity capacity in Indonesia currently exceeds 90 GW, with more than half supplied by coal and less than 15% from new renewable energy.

marketNews.title: Sonny Effendhi on Milk Industry Policy
marketNews.content: Sonny Effendhi, Executive Director of the Indonesian Dairy Processors Association, called on the government to focus on improving the quality of domestically produced fresh milk because locally-standard milk is still scarce. He also said the government’s proposal to impose import duties on milk would be counter-productive because it would raise the retail price of milk at a time when consumer purchasing power is already challenged. Deputy Minister of Cooperatives, Ferry Juliantono, said imported milk is cheaper by about 1,000-2,000 rupiah per litre. To encourage domestic milk consumption, the ministry proposes incentives for local farmers or a review of the potential imposition of import duties on milk.

marketNews.title: BEI launches Single Stock Futures (SSF)
marketNews.content: The Indonesia Stock Exchange launched a single-stock futures (SSF) product on Tuesday (12 November 2024). SSF is a derivative that allows investors to take long or short positions. The underlying stocks are the constituents of the LQ45 index. At the inaugural launch, 15 contracts were issued using five stocks as underlying: $ASII, $BBCA, $BBRI, $MDKA, and $TLKM. The exchange said only three member exchanges have so far provided SSF trading facilities.

marketNews.title: Nestlé and P&G investigate palm-oil sourcing after environmental groups’ claims
marketNews.content: Reuters reported that Nestlé and Procter & Gamble will investigate their palm-oil supply after environmental groups, including the Rainforest Action Network, found that the companies’ CPO supplies originated from illegal deforestation in protected forests in Indonesia. The investigation, conducted in September and October 2024, discovered that fresh fruit bunches from illegal plantations were sold to PT Global Sawit Semesta and PT Aceh Trumon Anugerah Kita, which supply major brands such as P&G, Nestlé, Mondelez and PepsiCo. The Ministry of Forestry has not commented on the issue.

tickerNews.title: AADI announces IPO and rights issue
tickerNews.content: $AADI: Anak ... Adaro Andalan Indonesia, a subsidiary of Adaro Energy Indonesia (ADRO), plans to issue 778.7 million (10%) new shares at a price range of 4,590-5,900 rupiah per share. The proceeds will be allocated 40% to loans to subsidiaries, 15% to repay part of a loan to PT Adaro Indonesia, and the remainder to repay part of a loan to ADRO. The offering is expected to run from 29 November to 3 December 2024, with an anticipated listing on the Indonesia Stock Exchange on 5 December 2024. In addition, AADI will conduct a shareholders’ rights issue simultaneously with the IPO. The corporate action is part of the spin-off of AADI from ADRO.

tickerNews.title: BREN purchase of 10 million BREN shares
tickerNews.content: $BREN: Indirect controller of Barito Renewables Energy, Prajogo Pangestu, bought 10 million BREN shares at an average price of 7,322 rupiah per share on 11 November 2024. The transaction value was about 73.2 billion rupiah, raising his ownership from 0.08954% to 0.09701%.

tickerNews.title: BBCA interim dividend announcement
tickerNews.content: $BBCA: Bank Central Asia will distribute an interim dividend for the 2024 fiscal year amounting to approximately 6.2 trillion rupiah or 50 rupiah per share. The cum-date is 20 November 2024 in the regular market, with payment on 12 December 2024. Using BBCA’s closing price on Tuesday (12/11) of 10,150 rupiah, the implied dividend yield is about 0.5%.

tickerNews.title: PTRO bond and sukuk issuance
tickerNews.content: $PTRO: Petrosea plans to issue a 1 trillion-rupiah bond and a 500 billion-rupiah sukuk, each consisting of four series. The interest rate has not been disclosed; the proceeds will be used for working-capital needs on mining projects and for engineering and construction. The bond and sukuk have each received an idA+ rating from Pefindo (idA+ sy). The public offering is expected to run on 9–10 December 2024.

tickerNews.title: TOBA buyback allocation adjustment
tickerNews.content: $TOBA: TBS Energi Utama announced a change in the buyback-fund allocation, reducing the maximum amount from US$30.8 million (IDR 474.5 billion) in the previous prospectus to a maximum of US$25.9 million (IDR 425.5 billion). The number of shares to be repurchased remains at a maximum of 816.8 million shares, or 10% of the paid-in capital. The plan will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders’ meeting on 14 November 2024.

tickerNews.title: IATA rights issue announcement
tickerNews.content: $IATA: MNC Energy Investments plans a rights issue of up to 20.2 billion new shares, resulting in a dilution of up to 44.44%. The issue price has not been disclosed; the proceeds will be used for working-capital needs and investments in subsidiaries.

tickerNews.title: LPCK rights issue
tickerNews.content: $LPCK: Lippo Cikarang plans a rights issue of 3 billion new shares with a dilutive effect of 52.82% and an undisclosed issue price. The proceeds will be used for working-capital needs and/or equity investment in subsidiaries. The plan will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders’ meeting on 19 November 2024.
